body: The day after the strike deadline came and went, the day after the city went to bed not knowing what to expect, it seemed yesterday that New Yorkers had finally started to take the threat of a transit strike seriously. And they were not happy. After serenely assuring themselves earlier this week that brinkmanship would not give way to an actual
title: TRANSIT NEGOTIATIONS: RIDERS; A Tense Wait For Word On Getting To One's Job

body: Throwing New Yorkers off balance with fluid deadlines and rigid demands, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the transit workers' union broke off talks yesterday morning, leading the union to call a strike against two Queens bus companies on Monday and the whole system on Tuesday if no settlement is reached. After the union's first
title: TRANSIT NEGOTIATIONS: OVERVIEW; New Transit Talks Set; Strike Is Put Off to Tuesday

body: Attractions Museums and Sites FRAUNCES TAVERN MUSEUM, 54 Pearl Street, second floor, Lower Manhattan. The museum, in a former tavern, is dedicated to the study and interpretation of early American history and culture. Tuesday night at 6:30, ''Sing We All Merrily,'' a musical celebration of an 18th-century Christmas, with Linda Russell & Companie;
title: Spare Times

body: It began this spring without explanation: fire hydrants, street signs and bicycles all over Park Slope and Carroll Gardens in Brooklyn were suddenly standing watch over their own distorted chalk outlines, as if anticipating some violent demise. Whoever did this left no clue other than an ambiguous signature: ''$; Ellis G. 2007,'' scrawled next to
title: Tracing Shadows; Brooklynite Finds Art Wherever Light Is Blocked

body: Bicyclists were elated when a major renovation of the Williamsburg Bridge finished two years ago included improvements to the pedestrian and bicycle path. But they were decidedly displeased at the addition of some two dozen steel plates that stuck up nearly two inches above the pathway. The raised plates covered joints in the bridge that allowed
title: Bridge Is So Smooth Now, Why Not Have Breakfast While You Ride?

body: Attractions Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. Through New Year's Day, the Origami Holiday Tree. The Rose Center is open on Friday nights until 8:45, for ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' with cash bar, jazz and tapas on the first Friday of every month. Tonight at 6 and 7:30, Chico
title: SPARE TIMES

body: The Gowanus Canal often stinks and is almost always spotted with slicks of oil. The streets alongside it are practically deserted, the silence broken by the rumble of concrete mixers and oil tankers or the screech of buzz saws. Graffiti abounds, and no one would use the word harmonious for the landscape, where ramshackle wood-frame and brick row
title: From Open Sewer to Open for Gentrification; Many Gowanus Residents Want Its Collar to Remain Blue

body: Attractions Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. Through May 29, ''Darwin,'' an exhibition devoted to the naturalist that includes live creatures and fossils, as well as a reconstruction of the study at his home, Down House in Kent, where he wrote ''On the Origin of Species.'' Through New Year's
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Manhattan CHINATOWN $340,000 215 Park Row (Pearl Street) (Gotham Green) 480-sq.-ft. studio co-op in a postwar building; 24-hr. doormen; eat-in kitchen, hardwood floors, south and east exposure; maintenance $415, 46% tax-deductible; listed at $340,000, 5 weeks on market (broker: Weichert Realtors/Mazzeo) CHELSEA $2.7 million 144 West 18th Street

body: DEAR DIARY: I'm a chocolatier, and I enjoy selling my creations at the Columbus Avenue flea market. Last year, a week or two before Thanksgiving, a young woman was admiring my chocolate turkeys and other seasonal items when she picked up a chocolate pilgrim-shaped lollipop and exclaimed, ''I love the little leprechauns!'' Debbie Eiser Dear Diary:
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: THE question sounded laughable: Given that the national median home price recently calculated by the National Association of Realtors is $220,000, is it possible to buy something for that price in New York City? Or even, just to provide some wiggle room, up to $250,000? The initial reactions of real estate brokers in all five boroughs included:
title: What You Can Get for $220,000

body: Attractions Museums and Sites MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''Dutch Days Tour,'' a tour of the galleries that highlight Dutch influence in the city. Also tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''The Creatures -- Tales from the Bush,'' a family presentation of Yoruba parables by Orisha Tales Production; a
title: Spare Times

body: Only two restaurants outside Manhattan won stars in the new Michelin Guide for New York, Peter Luger and Saul, and both are in Brooklyn. In all, 25 Brooklyn restaurants were listed, with places on Smith and Court Streets dominating. Here are some high points (star ratings are by New York Times). BANANIA CAFE (718) 237-9100; 241 Smith Street
title: GOOD EATING/SMITH AND COURT STREETS; Bon App√©tit

body: Six years ago, Philipp Angermeyer bought an apartment in the Carroll Gardens Landmark Condominiums, a 19th-century Romanesque church turned residential building on Court Street in Brooklyn. In part, the appeal of living in the landmark church is architectural: stained-glass windows, high ceilings and a certain monastic quietude. Over the summer,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; When a Church Is Not a Home

body: THE evolution of David Scott's Red Hook loft from party pad to stylishly designed apartment tracked the 38-year-old's personal growth. Once a stay-up-all-night bachelor, he is now a married entrepreneur who goes to bed around 9 p.m. so he can get an early start on his work -- making modern furniture for his own Brooklyn-based design firm. When Mr.
title: HABITATS/Red Hook, Brooklyn; The History of a Loft Reflects The His-and-Her Story of a Couple

body: WHILE the narrow, slow-moving waterway in Brooklyn known as the Gowanus Canal has not been called ''Lavender Lake'' for some time, it remains an occasionally fetid and sludge-slicked thoroughfare. It is home to industrial businesses, infrequent boat visits and a growing contingent of marine life. Yet the canal, sandwiched between the real estate
title: LIVING IN/Gowanus, Brooklyn; Some See Venice; Some See a Canal

Tonight from 6 to 10, ''Death at Home: Ghostly Tales and Tours by Candlelight,'' a tour of the house as it was decorated for 19th-century home funerals, followed by tales of the ghosts that are said to inhabit the museum. body: WHEN Carroll Gardens was developed in the 1840's, the homes on the ''place'' streets in that Brooklyn neighborhood were sold with long front yards -- courtyards -- and deeds stipulating that they must be retained. If you bought a brownstone on Third Place, for instance, you could plant a pine tree or tend a garden, as many people who live there do,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; Buicks Amid the Bushes

body: MY garden, if ever a term has been so generously applied, yielded a special crop this year: weeds from another garden. I noticed them one morning recently while picking up after the dog: thigh-high weeds uprooted and tucked carefully between the hibiscus and the stone facade of my building, bunched together like a sheaf of slightly greenish wheat
title: URBAN STUDIES/Planting; Her Not So Secret Garden

body: AS with most birthday parties for 1-year-olds, the guest of honor didn't really know what was going on. A Brooklyn band, Have Her Home by Ten, was celebrating its first anniversary last weekend with a prom-themed all-nighter at the Bitter End, the legendary Greenwich Village bar where Bob Dylan and Bruce Springsteen played as they were hitting the
title: URBAN TACTICS; The Band Just Wants to Have Fun

body: Cary McWilliam, a freelance modern dancer and teacher in Manhattan who earns about $23,000 a year, loves the freedom of leaping from one job to the next, unbeholden to any single employer. But that same independence takes a toll on her finances and her nerves. ''With the inconsistent paycheck,'' she said, ''it's hard to save. My retirement is
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; The Highs and Lows of Going It Alone

body: BROOKLYN should need no introduction: ancestors of as many as one in four Americans are said to have once called it home. But New York's most populous borough -- with about 2.5 million residents representing more than 90 ethnic groups -- has always been shadowed by its glamorous neighbor across the East River. Thriving a century ago, Brooklyn fell
title: 36 HOURS; Brooklyn

body: The four Democratic mayoral candidates aggressively courted voters yesterday on the eve of today's primary, with Fernando Ferrer making an appeal to black and Hispanic New Yorkers in hopes of winning the primary and avoiding a runoff, while the three others tried to energize their core supporters to vote in a race where turnout is the big unknown.
title: CAMPAIGNING FOR CITY HALL: THE CANDIDATES; Mayoral Hopefuls Traverse New York in Primary Race

author: Jerome Charyn, who teaches film theory at the American University in Paris, is the author of 10 crime novels featuring a New York police officer, among them ''El Bronx,'' ''Citizen Sidel'' and ''The Isaac Quartet.''
body: MOST New Yorkers have a jolting memory of where they were on 9/11, when the twin towers tumbled, leaving Lower Manhattan in a black void for 10 minutes until the smoke and dust clouds began to clear. I couldn't witness the smoke, the dust, the debris. I was sitting in my lawyer's office on the Avenue Henri-Martin, in Paris, when his sister called
title: The Enduring Salute

body: Babies were born, and then they walked, and a contentious presidential race came and went. There were two heat waves, a blackout and 665 Yankees and Mets home games. Scores of fresh New Yorkers, from Calcutta and Kalamazoo, whose memories of the 2001 attack on the city were formed by the television screen, have rolled up to the gates of the
title: With a Wrench of the Gut; A Sight or a Sound Can Bring 9/11 Flooding Back

body: THE residents at the Sheffield, a 50-story apartment building near Central Park, believed their King Midas moment had finally arrived. Their building had just been sold for $418 million, and the new owners wanted to convert the rental building into a luxury condominium. They had heard the El Dorado tales of how renters sometimes got amazing deals
title: The End Of The Fabled Insider Deal

body: The shoppers and young families strolling along Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, can normally slurp their iced coffees, nosh on bagels and French pastries and browse for books far from the tumultuous politics of City Hall. But now it seems they cannot escape the mayoral candidates and their campaign workers prospecting for votes, as
title: Mayoral Rivals Fight for Turf in Brownstone Brooklyn

body: On a cool night last week, the small dining space at Panino'teca 275, a sandwich and wine bar on the Smith Street restaurant row in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, was crowded. In the restaurant's vast back patio, though, sat eight empty tables, each with six unused seats. Out front, a chalkboard that read ''The Garden Is Open!'' was marked over with a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SMITH STREET, BROOKLYN; At These Garden Patios, Empty Tables Bloom

body: City residents longing for rolling green pastures can find them at the southwest corner of Sackett and Columbia Streets in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. A vacant lot has been given berms and grass (top left), and some nights one wall comes alive (bottom left) with moving images of grazing cows or horses. The multimedia work is by Julie Farris, a
title: CURRENTS: SIDEWALK ART; In Bosky Brooklyn, Cows and Horses Come Out After Dark

body: As the 4 p.m. sun ducked behind an accommodating cloud last weekend, two shirtless men of considerable girth discovered they were neighbors. Sipping frothy beverages with their feet tucked into the sand, the neighbors, from Woodside, Queens, reflected on their good fortune. They had discovered a beach on the East River. ''Ain't like taking the 53
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY; On the Beach, Courtesy of New Jersey

title: Spare Times

body: There are a baby's handful of people in this city you can point to and say, ''That's who folks come to New York to be'' -- Mayor Mike from Boston, Bobby Short from Danville, Ill., and Kate Spade from Kansas City, to name a few. Kurt Andersen from Omaha, to name another. Andersen, 50, whose r√©sum√© is as diverse as Leonardo's, has been a literary
title: KITCHEN VOYEUR; Kitchen Sage

body: There was a restaurant in Greenwich Village called Le Zoo, and it was good, and it was cheap, and now, like so many others of its kind, it is gone. It was not the sort of place that drew tourists clutching their Zagats, but it swelled each night with young hipsters and people from the neighborhood, who sipped red wine at the bar and ate $6.50 trout
title: Yesterday's Special: Good, Cheap Dining; The Reasonable One-Star Grows Rarer in Manhattan

body: Walking Tours New York City GREEN-WOOD CEMETERY, Brooklyn. A look at the architecture, sculpture and history of the cemetery, led by John Cashman, meeting Sunday at 1 p.m. at the gate at Fort Hamilton Parkway, off McDonald Avenue. Fee, $6. title: Spare Times

author: Jenny Allen is a contributing editor at Good Housekeeping and a stand-up comic.
body: MY friend Ashton and her boyfriend, Bob, are leaving Ashton's roomy, prewar apartment on West End Avenue and buying a two-story house in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. They are not making a real estate killing, the only reason I would consider budging from the Upper West Side. Like many of my fellow middle-aged Upper West Siders, I am hanging on for dear
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/BACKLASH; They'll Take Manhattan

body: AS a convert to Brooklyn's charms, I like to think I was ahead of the curve. We were driving back from a camping trip somewhere upstate, my parents, my brother and me, squeezed into my father's pickup truck, the back piled high with tents and sleeping bags. I must have been about 12. The detour wasn't even on the way back to our house on eastern
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/SIGNS OF CHANGING TIMES; Two Guys From the Hood

body: HERE'S an exercise. Google the words ''New Brooklyn'' and see how many hits you come up with. The answer: 15.7 million. Even allowing for the insane inclusiveness of an Internet search, that number reveals something profound about the frenzy -- cultural, gastronomic, architectural and otherwise -- that has seized what is affectionately known as
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/FACES OF A BOROUGH; Who Hurts?

body: THIS is how it happens. Priced out of Manhattan, you move from a shoebox in the East Village to a quiet, tree-lined neighborhood in Brooklyn, Carroll Gardens, say, or Park Slope. Or maybe you hole up in an underfurnished loft in Williamsburg. This is a temporary, even unexpected move. Somehow, in your imaginings of life in New York, the Jay
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/SIGNS OF CHANGING TIMES; Two Guys From the Hood

body: 1802 -- A land speculator named Richard M. Woodhull, who operates a ferry service from Manhattan to Metropolitan Avenue, buys 13 acres and names the area Williamsburgh, after Col. Jonathan Williams, the man who surveyed the land. But trendiness is still two centuries away; Woodhull declares bankruptcy after selling only a few lots. 1855 -- At the
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/TIPPING POINTS; How Williamsburg Got Its Groove

body: Williamsburg Village Style Freddy Jakubowski has tended bar at the Greenpoint Tavern on Bedford Avenue since 1985. It was 1992 when a place arrived unlike any other there, a little restaurant called the L Cafe. "Some girl opened it," Mr. Jakubowski said. "She was a good girl. I'm not much of an architect or a decorator, but she did it something
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/TIPPING POINTS; The Day When Back in the Day Ended

author: Compiled by Kris Ensminger
body: Fine Brooklyn dining was once pretty much synonymous with Peter Luger and the River Caf√©. But the transformation of the borough's restaurant scene has spawned Brooklyn's own Zagat guide and a number of relatively new places that have earned at least one star from The New York Times. body: A feeling of the unsettled past had settled over St. Mary Star of the Sea Church in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, in recent days. Rather than shrug it off, the church's organist, Salvatore Mazzucco, who has a keen ear for long and trembling notes, seized it with a plan. Memorial Day was approaching, he told the Rev. title: Filling In a Memorial's Blank Space; A Church's War Dead Will Be Nameless No More

body: To the Editor: Reading about Edward Kent's crusade to furnish cashiers at Morton Williams University Supermarket with stools to sit on while they work (''As They Ring It Up, Should They Be Sitting Down?,'' May 15) reminded me of the first time I saw this practice: England, in 1986. Every supermarket I shopped at allowed the workers to sit during
title: Give Cashiers a Break

Getting to know a new neighborhood is always a process of locating and evaluating the essentials -- grocery store, laundry,
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Comfort Food

title: PUBLIC LIVES; An Architect Who Also Clears Away

body: When the red-brick building at 350 Bond Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, was new, sometime in the mid-1800's, it was near the middle of a busy shipping center. Barges on the Gowanus Canal, new itself and only a block away, would unload goods to be carted off to far-flung merchants. The cargo was pulled by horses, and when those horses finished
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; The Hay Long Gone, A Stable Follows Suit

body: COLUMBIA STREET, a 1.3-mile stretch of low-rise buildings running along the Brooklyn waterfront, has known good times, bad times and some really terrible times. But now, with the recent announcement that the piers it faces, owned by the Port Authority, will be used for cruise lines, it seems highly likely that Columbia Street will watch its own
title: SQUARE FEET; On the Waterfront in Brooklyn, an Enclave Regains Its Energy

body: NEW YORK CITY real estate agents are beginning to hear a rumbling under them, something that makes them stop cold and stand at full attention: the sound of sellers asking, ''Do I have to pay 6 percent?'' Although the vast majority of commissions in Manhattan are still at 6 percent, some sellers realize that, with agents starved for listings and
title: Are Commissions Really Negotiable? Sort of.

title: GOOD EATING; Off-Street Dining

body: ONE Saturday last month, Leon Reid donned a hard hat and an orange worker's tunic and headed for a busy corner in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, where he bolted a bent telephone sign onto the top of a Verizon phone booth and screwed a crinkled one-way sign onto the top of a nearby pole. People drifted past, noticing nothing suspicious in their midst.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN AND BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Bending, Bolting And Evading The Police

title: THE AGE OF DISSONANCE; No Sleep Till Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: After 35 years as a public school teacher, I can say that the only ''experts'' never consulted about the school system's problems are teachers. title: Our Teachers and Principals

body: Roman Catholics poured into cathedrals and parish churches across the United States on Tuesday to celebrate Masses of Thanksgiving for the new pope, Benedict XVI, but the choice of Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger as pope prompted strong disagreement over what he would mean for the American church. Some liberal Catholics and interest groups criticized the
title: POPE BENEDICT XVI: U.S. REACTION; For America's Divided Roman Catholics, a New Difference of Opinion

author: Ben Gibberd is writing a book called ''On the Edge,'' about people who live and work along the New York waterfront.
body: FOR hundreds of Brooklyn children, this coming Thursday is a day they have been waiting for all winter. That is the day when Kathleen Henderson, aka the Park Lady, will emerge from the mysterious regions to which she returns during the winter and once more take up residence in her summer home, which is Carroll Park in Carroll Gardens. There, from 9
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; The Park Lady and Her Peaceable Kingdom

body: Three Roman Catholic elementary schools in Brooklyn and Queens that had been scheduled for closing received joyous news yesterday as they began their Easter vacations: the Brooklyn Diocese approved emergency business plans drawn up by the pupils' parents and agreed to keep the schools open as long as they meet the plans' goals. The three schools --
title: Three Schools in the Brooklyn Diocese Are Given Reprieves

body: THERE'S a tambourine in Adam Pierce's bedroom, two upright pianos and some Balinese gamelan instruments in his living room, a Celtic harp near his television set. Piled up next to the basement stairs are four drum kits in their cases. Take a left at the laundry room and there's the recording studio, a low-ceiling den where drums, a guitar and a
title: MUSIC; Home Sweet Studio

body: IN any kind of remotely fair Battle of the Saints, Joseph would smite Patrick all over the firmament. Patrick may be the patron saint of Ireland, but Joseph married the woman who soon gave birth to the savior of all Christendom. Down here in the United States, Patrick is the marquee name. Joseph's feast day falls two days after St. Patrick's, and
title: INK; After the Wearing of the Green, a Duel of Pastries

body: THERE'S a lot riding on a restaurant sequel. Like its cinematic counterparts, it has to gratify die-hard fans while gaining new ones. In Brooklyn, the three-month-old Bouillabaisse 126 is to the late, great La Bouillabaisse what, say, ''Road Warrior'' was to the original ''Mad Max.'' It reinterprets the original's low-budget, indie cool for wider
title: $25 AND UNDER; For a French Second Act, a Wardrobe Change

body: A day after spring seemed to burst out of hiding, winter came charging back to the New York region yesterday with a storm that brought plunging temperatures and wind-whipped snow that appeared strangely immune to gravity -- blowing up and sideways as well as down. From street corners, office windows and front porches, many watched in dismay as the
title: In Wind, Snow, Cold and Frustration, a Dangerous Storm

body: MANY New Yorkers think they can do better than ''The World's Second Home,'' the phrase that the Bloomberg administration wants to trademark as New York's official slogan. body: Snow was slowly covering the handsome streets and stoops of Carroll Gardens, a reminder that winter wasn't ready to surrender and an incentive to hurry into Crave. When it's frigid and difficult outside, you want something warm and cozy. You want an unassuming hug of a place. Crave fits the bill. In the felicitous words of one of its chefs and
title: Diner's Journal

body: In March 1999, shortly after a fire destroyed a signal relay room at a Brooklyn subway station, an internal investigation by New York City Transit determined that smoke detectors and fire-retardant material should be installed at all relay rooms throughout the system, according to agency documents. Nearly six years later, at least 40 of those
title: Fire Prevention in Subway Signal Rooms Was Urged After 1999 Blaze

body: A subway fire severely damaged a signal relay room in Lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon, and transit officials warned last night that service on the A and the C, two of the city's busiest subway lines, would be suspended or sharply reduced throughout today. The A, C and E lines were rerouted following the 2 p.m. fire at the Chambers Street
title: SNOWSTORM IN THE NORTHEAST: THE SUBWAYS; Signal Room Fire Reroutes Trains on 3 Subway Lines

body: SANDWICHED between Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant, Clinton Hill in Brooklyn might just be the quintessence of urban living in New York City. It is affluent and not so, seedy and grand, ethnically diverse, a magnet for artists, musicians and filmmakers, and so rich in architectural style that even now, with escalating property prices, a new
title: LIVING IN/Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; Into the Big Leagues, With Prices to Match

body: The day after the strike deadline came and went, the day after the city went to bed not knowing what to expect, it seemed yesterday that New Yorkers had finally started to take the threat of a transit strike seriously. And they were not happy. After serenely assuring themselves earlier this week that brinkmanship would not give way to an actual
title: TRANSIT NEGOTIATIONS: RIDERS; A Tense Wait For Word On Getting To One's Job

body: Throwing New Yorkers off balance with fluid deadlines and rigid demands, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the transit workers' union broke off talks yesterday morning, leading the union to call a strike against two Queens bus companies on Monday and the whole system on Tuesday if no settlement is reached. After the union's first
title: TRANSIT NEGOTIATIONS: OVERVIEW; New Transit Talks Set; Strike Is Put Off to Tuesday

body: Attractions Museums and Sites FRAUNCES TAVERN MUSEUM, 54 Pearl Street, second floor, Lower Manhattan. The museum, in a former tavern, is dedicated to the study and interpretation of early American history and culture. title: Spare Times

body: It began this spring without explanation: fire hydrants, street signs and bicycles all over Park Slope and Carroll Gardens in Brooklyn were suddenly standing watch over their own distorted chalk outlines, as if anticipating some violent demise. Whoever did this left no clue other than an ambiguous signature: ''$; Ellis G. 2007,'' scrawled next to
title: Tracing Shadows; Brooklynite Finds Art Wherever Light Is Blocked

body: Bicyclists were elated when a major renovation of the Williamsburg Bridge finished two years ago included improvements to the pedestrian and bicycle path. But they were decidedly displeased at the addition of some two dozen steel plates that stuck up nearly two inches above the pathway. The raised plates covered joints in the bridge that allowed
title: Bridge Is So Smooth Now, Why Not Have Breakfast While You Ride?

title: SPARE TIMES

body: The Gowanus Canal often stinks and is almost always spotted with slicks of oil. The streets alongside it are practically deserted, the silence broken by the rumble of concrete mixers and oil tankers or the screech of buzz saws. Graffiti abounds, and no one would use the word harmonious for the landscape, where ramshackle wood-frame and brick row
title: From Open Sewer to Open for Gentrification; Many Gowanus Residents Want Its Collar to Remain Blue

body: Attractions Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. Through May 29, ''Darwin,'' an exhibition devoted to the naturalist that includes live creatures and fossils, as well as a reconstruction of the study at his home, Down House in Kent, where he wrote ''On the Origin of Species.'' title: SPARE TIMES

body: DEAR DIARY: I'm a chocolatier, and I enjoy selling my creations at the Columbus Avenue flea market. Last year, a week or two before Thanksgiving, a young woman was admiring my chocolate turkeys and other seasonal items when she picked up a chocolate pilgrim-shaped lollipop and exclaimed, ''I love the little leprechauns!'' Debbie Eiser Dear Diary:
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: THE question sounded laughable: Given that the national median home price recently calculated by the National Association of Realtors is $220,000, is it possible to buy something for that price in New York City? Or even, just to provide some wiggle room, up to $250,000? The initial reactions of real estate brokers in all five boroughs included:
title: What You Can Get for $220,000

title: Spare Times

body: Only two restaurants outside Manhattan won stars in the new Michelin Guide for New York, Peter Luger and Saul, and both are in Brooklyn. In all, 25 Brooklyn restaurants were listed, with places on Smith and Court Streets dominating. Here are some high points (star ratings are by New York Times). BANANIA CAFE (718) 237-9100; 241 Smith Street

body: Six years ago, Philipp Angermeyer bought an apartment in the Carroll Gardens Landmark Condominiums, a 19th-century Romanesque church turned residential building on Court Street in Brooklyn. In part, the appeal of living in the landmark church is architectural: stained-glass windows, high ceilings and a certain monastic quietude. Over the summer,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; When a Church Is Not a Home

body: THE evolution of David Scott's Red Hook loft from party pad to stylishly designed apartment tracked the 38-year-old's personal growth. Once a stay-up-all-night bachelor, he is now a married entrepreneur who goes to bed around 9 p.m. so he can get an early start on his work -- making modern furniture for his own Brooklyn-based design firm. When Mr.
title: HABITATS/Red Hook, Brooklyn; The History of a Loft Reflects The His-and-Her Story of a Couple

body: WHILE the narrow, slow-moving waterway in Brooklyn known as the Gowanus Canal has not been called ''Lavender Lake'' for some time, it remains an occasionally fetid and sludge-slicked thoroughfare. It is home to industrial businesses, infrequent boat visits and a growing contingent of marine life. Yet the canal, sandwiched between the real estate
title: LIVING IN/Gowanus, Brooklyn; Some See Venice; Some See a Canal

body: WHEN Carroll Gardens was developed in the 1840's, the homes on the ''place'' streets in that Brooklyn neighborhood were sold with long front yards -- courtyards -- and deeds stipulating that they must be retained. If you bought a brownstone on Third Place, for instance, you could plant a pine tree or tend a garden, as many people who live there do,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; Buicks Amid the Bushes

body: MY garden, if ever a term has been so generously applied, yielded a special crop this year: weeds from another garden. I noticed them one morning recently while picking up after the dog: thigh-high weeds uprooted and tucked carefully between the hibiscus and the stone facade of my building, bunched together like a sheaf of slightly greenish wheat
title: URBAN STUDIES/Planting; Her Not So Secret Garden

body: AS with most birthday parties for 1-year-olds, the guest of honor didn't really know what was going on. A Brooklyn band, Have Her Home by Ten, was celebrating its first anniversary last weekend with a prom-themed all-nighter at the Bitter End, the legendary Greenwich Village bar where Bob Dylan and Bruce Springsteen played as they were hitting the
title: URBAN TACTICS; The Band Just Wants to Have Fun

body: Cary McWilliam, a freelance modern dancer and teacher in Manhattan who earns about $23,000 a year, loves the freedom of leaping from one job to the next, unbeholden to any single employer. But that same independence takes a toll on her finances and her nerves. ''With the inconsistent paycheck,'' she said, ''it's hard to save. My retirement is
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; The Highs and Lows of Going It Alone

body: BROOKLYN should need no introduction: ancestors of as many as one in four Americans are said to have once called it home. But New York's most populous borough -- with about 2.5 million residents representing more than 90 ethnic groups -- has always been shadowed by its glamorous neighbor across the East River. Thriving a century ago, Brooklyn fell
title: 36 HOURS; Brooklyn

body: The four Democratic mayoral candidates aggressively courted voters yesterday on the eve of today's primary, with Fernando Ferrer making an appeal to black and Hispanic New Yorkers in hopes of winning the primary and avoiding a runoff, while the three others tried to energize their core supporters to vote in a race where turnout is the big unknown.
title: CAMPAIGNING FOR CITY HALL: THE CANDIDATES; Mayoral Hopefuls Traverse New York in Primary Race

author: Jerome Charyn, who teaches film theory at the American University in Paris, is the author of 10 crime novels featuring a New York police officer, among them ''El Bronx,'' ''Citizen Sidel'' and ''The Isaac Quartet.''
body: MOST New Yorkers have a jolting memory of where they were on 9/11, when the twin towers tumbled, leaving Lower Manhattan in a black void for 10 minutes until the smoke and dust clouds began to clear. I couldn't witness the smoke, the dust, the debris. I was sitting in my lawyer's office on the Avenue Henri-Martin, in Paris, when his sister called
title: The Enduring Salute

body: Babies were born, and then they walked, and a contentious presidential race came and went. There were two heat waves, a blackout and 665 Yankees and Mets home games. Scores of fresh New Yorkers, from Calcutta and Kalamazoo, whose memories of the 2001 attack on the city were formed by the television screen, have rolled up to the gates of the
title: With a Wrench of the Gut; A Sight or a Sound Can Bring 9/11 Flooding Back

body: THE residents at the Sheffield, a 50-story apartment building near Central Park, believed their King Midas moment had finally arrived. Their building had just been sold for $418 million, and the new owners wanted to convert the rental building into a luxury condominium. They had heard the El Dorado tales of how renters sometimes got amazing deals
title: The End Of The Fabled Insider Deal

body: The shoppers and young families strolling along Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, can normally slurp their iced coffees, nosh on bagels and French pastries and browse for books far from the tumultuous politics of City Hall. But now it seems they cannot escape the mayoral candidates and their campaign workers prospecting for votes, as
title: Mayoral Rivals Fight for Turf in Brownstone Brooklyn

body: On a cool night last week, the small dining space at Panino'teca 275, a sandwich and wine bar on the Smith Street restaurant row in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, was crowded. In the restaurant's vast back patio, though, sat eight empty tables, each with six unused seats. Out front, a chalkboard that read ''The Garden Is Open!'' was marked over with a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SMITH STREET, BROOKLYN; At These Garden Patios, Empty Tables Bloom

body: City residents longing for rolling green pastures can find them at the southwest corner of Sackett and Columbia Streets in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. A vacant lot has been given berms and grass (top left), and some nights one wall comes alive (bottom left) with moving images of grazing cows or horses. The multimedia work is by Julie Farris, a
title: CURRENTS: SIDEWALK ART; In Bosky Brooklyn, Cows and Horses Come Out After Dark

body: As the 4 p.m. sun ducked behind an accommodating cloud last weekend, two shirtless men of considerable girth discovered they were neighbors. Sipping frothy beverages with their feet tucked into the sand, the neighbors, from Woodside, Queens, reflected on their good fortune. They had discovered a beach on the East River. ''Ain't like taking the 53
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY; On the Beach, Courtesy of New Jersey

title: KITCHEN VOYEUR; Kitchen Sage

body: There was a restaurant in Greenwich Village called Le Zoo, and it was good, and it was cheap, and now, like so many others of its kind, it is gone. It was not the sort of place that drew tourists clutching their Zagats, but it swelled each night with young hipsters and people from the neighborhood, who sipped red wine at the bar and ate $6.50 trout
title: Yesterday's Special: Good, Cheap Dining; The Reasonable One-Star Grows Rarer in Manhattan

title: Spare Times

author: Jenny Allen is a contributing editor at Good Housekeeping and a stand-up comic.
body: MY friend Ashton and her boyfriend, Bob, are leaving Ashton's roomy, prewar apartment on West End Avenue and buying a two-story house in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. They are not making a real estate killing, the only reason I would consider budging from the Upper West Side. Like many of my fellow middle-aged Upper West Siders, I am hanging on for dear
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/BACKLASH; They'll Take Manhattan

body: AS a convert to Brooklyn's charms, I like to think I was ahead of the curve. We were driving back from a camping trip somewhere upstate, my parents, my brother and me, squeezed into my father's pickup truck, the back piled high with tents and sleeping bags. I must have been about 12. The detour wasn't even on the way back to our house on eastern
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/SIGNS OF CHANGING TIMES; Two Guys From the Hood

body: HERE'S an exercise. Google the words ''New Brooklyn'' and see how many hits you come up with. The answer: 15.7 million. title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/FACES OF A BOROUGH; Who Hurts?

body: THIS is how it happens. Priced out of Manhattan, you move from a shoebox in the East Village to a quiet, tree-lined neighborhood in Brooklyn, Carroll Gardens, say, or Park Slope. Or maybe you hole up in an underfurnished loft in Williamsburg. This is a temporary, even unexpected move. Somehow, in your imaginings of life in New York, the Jay
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/SIGNS OF CHANGING TIMES; Two Guys From the Hood

body: 1802 -- A land speculator named Richard M. Woodhull, who operates a ferry service from Manhattan to Metropolitan Avenue, buys 13 acres and names the area Williamsburgh, after Col. Jonathan Williams, the man who surveyed the land. But trendiness is still two centuries away; Woodhull declares bankruptcy after selling only a few lots. 1855 -- At the
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/TIPPING POINTS; How Williamsburg Got Its Groove

body: Williamsburg Village Style Freddy Jakubowski has tended bar at the Greenpoint Tavern on Bedford Avenue since 1985. It was 1992 when a place arrived unlike any other there, a little restaurant called the L Cafe. "Some girl opened it," Mr. Jakubowski said. "She was a good girl. I'm not much of an architect or a decorator, but she did it something
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/TIPPING POINTS; The Day When Back in the Day Ended

title: Filling In a Memorial's Blank Space; A Church's War Dead Will Be Nameless No More

title: Give Cashiers a Break

body: When the red-brick building at 350 Bond Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, was new, sometime in the mid-1800's, it was near the middle of a busy shipping center. Barges on the Gowanus Canal, new itself and only a block away, would unload goods to be carted off to far-flung merchants. The cargo was pulled by horses, and when those horses finished
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; The Hay Long Gone, A Stable Follows Suit

title: SQUARE FEET; On the Waterfront in Brooklyn, an Enclave Regains Its Energy

Although the vast majority of commissions in Manhattan are still at 6 percent, some sellers realize that, with agents starved for listings and
title: Are Commissions Really Negotiable? Sort of.

People drifted past, noticing nothing suspicious in their midst.

body: Roman Catholics poured into cathedrals and parish churches across the United States on Tuesday to celebrate Masses of Thanksgiving for the new pope, Benedict XVI, but the choice of Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger as pope prompted strong disagreement over what he would mean for the American church. title: POPE BENEDICT XVI: U.S. REACTION; For America's Divided Roman Catholics, a New Difference of Opinion

body: FOR hundreds of Brooklyn children, this coming Thursday is a day they have been waiting for all winter. There, from 9
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; The Park Lady and Her Peaceable Kingdom

body: Three Roman Catholic elementary schools in Brooklyn and Queens that had been scheduled for closing received joyous news yesterday as they began their Easter vacations: the Brooklyn Diocese approved emergency business plans drawn up by the pupils' parents and agreed to keep the schools open as long as they meet the plans' goals. The three schools --
title: Three Schools in the Brooklyn Diocese Are Given Reprieves

body: THERE'S a tambourine in Adam Pierce's bedroom, two upright pianos and some Balinese gamelan instruments in his living room, a Celtic harp near his television set. Piled up next to the basement stairs are four drum kits in their cases. Take a left at the laundry room and there's the recording studio, a low-ceiling den where drums, a guitar and a
title: MUSIC; Home Sweet Studio

body: IN any kind of remotely fair Battle of the Saints, Joseph would smite Patrick all over the firmament. Patrick may be the patron saint of Ireland, but Joseph married the woman who soon gave birth to the savior of all Christendom. Down here in the United States, Patrick is the marquee name. Joseph's feast day falls two days after St. Patrick's, and
title: INK; After the Wearing of the Green, a Duel of Pastries

body: THERE'S a lot riding on a restaurant sequel. Like its cinematic counterparts, it has to gratify die-hard fans while gaining new ones. In Brooklyn, the three-month-old Bouillabaisse 126 is to the late, great La Bouillabaisse what, say, ''Road Warrior'' was to the original ''Mad Max.'' It reinterprets the original's low-budget, indie cool for wider
title: $25 AND UNDER; For a French Second Act, a Wardrobe Change

body: A day after spring seemed to burst out of hiding, winter came charging back to the New York region yesterday with a storm that brought plunging temperatures and wind-whipped snow that appeared strangely immune to gravity -- blowing up and sideways as well as down. From street corners, office windows and front porches, many watched in dismay as the
title: In Wind, Snow, Cold and Frustration, a Dangerous Storm

title: Diner's Journal

title: PERSONAL SHOPPER; Who Needs A Flying Carpet?

body: In March 1999, shortly after a fire destroyed a signal relay room at a Brooklyn subway station, an internal investigation by New York City Transit determined that smoke detectors and fire-retardant material should be installed at all relay rooms throughout the system, according to agency documents. Nearly six years later, at least 40 of those
title: Fire Prevention in Subway Signal Rooms Was Urged After 1999 Blaze

body: A subway fire severely damaged a signal relay room in Lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon, and transit officials warned last night that service on the A and the C, two of the city's busiest subway lines, would be suspended or sharply reduced throughout today. The A, C and E lines were rerouted following the 2 p.m. fire at the Chambers Street
title: SNOWSTORM IN THE NORTHEAST: THE SUBWAYS; Signal Room Fire Reroutes Trains on 3 Subway Lines

body: SANDWICHED between Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant, Clinton Hill in Brooklyn might just be the quintessence of urban living in New York City. It is affluent and not so, seedy and grand, ethnically diverse, a magnet for artists, musicians and filmmakers, and so rich in architectural style that even now, with escalating property prices, a new
title: LIVING IN/Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; Into the Big Leagues, With Prices to Match
